{{Use mdy dates|date=June 2018}} [[File:Madonna - Rebel Heart Tour Cologne 2 (23219532496) (cropped).jpg|thumb|Madonna, seen here on the [[Rebel Heart Tour]] (2015), has had a social-cultural impact on the world through her artistic endeavors.]] Since the beginning of her career in the early 1980s, American singer and songwriter [[Madonna (entertainer)|Madonna]] has had a social-cultural impact on the world through her recordings, attitude, clothing and lifestyle. Called the "[[Honorific nicknames in popular music|Queen of Pop]]", Madonna is labeled by international authors as the greatest woman in music, as well as the most influential and iconic female recording artist of all time.
Accepted as a global [[cultural icon]], Madonna has built a legacy that goes beyond music and has been studied by [[sociologists]], [[List of historians|historians]] and other [[social scientists]].<ref name="Batanga"/> Her impact is often compared with that of [[The Beatles' influence on popular culture|The Beatles]] and [[Cultural impact of Elvis Presley|Elvis Presley]]; they are the [[List of best-selling music artists|best selling acts of all time]] in the general, solo male and female category respectively.<ref name="Herman">{{harvnb|Herman|2009|pp=286}}</ref> Madonna is a key figure in [[popular music]]; critics have retrospectively credited her presence, success and contributions with paving the way for every female artist and changing forever the music scene for women in the music history, as well as for today's pop stars. Even [[Bibliography of Madonna|reviews of her work]] have served as a roadmap for scrutinizing women at each stage in their music career.<ref name="Noisey">{{Cite news|url=http://noisey.vice.com/blog/madonna-bedtime-stories-20th-anniversary-sex-sexuality-feminism|title=WHY MADONNA'S UNAPOLOGETIC 'BEDTIME STORIES' IS HER MOST IMPORTANT ALBUM|date=October 24, 2014|accessdate=June 22, 2013|last=von Aue|first=Mary|work=[[Vice (magazine)|Vice]] Magazine}}</ref>
Madonna is the first multimedia [[pop icon]] in history and professionals agree that she has become the world's biggest and most socially significant pop icon, as well as the most controversial. However, some intellectuals, like the Frenchman [[Georges Claude Guilbert]], felt that she has greater cultural importance, like a [[myth]], that has apparent universality and timelessness. References to Madonna in [[popular culture]] are found in the arts, food, science and each branch of entertainment. In a general sense, journalist [[Peter Robinson (journalist)|Peter Robinson]] noted that "Madonna invented contemporary pop fame so there is a little bit of her in the DNA of every modern pop thing."<ref name="GuardianPopstars"/>
However, she is not only an omnipresent figure, but also a [[Polarization (psychology)|polarizing]] one. During her career, Madonna has attracted contradictory cultural social attention from family organizations, feminist "anti-porn" and religious groups worldwide with boycott and protests. Although this attracted unprecedented world media attention, the reviews have been negative, resulting sometimes in censorships.
== Cultural and social impact == Madonna has been described as an "omnipresent" character and one of the most recognizable names and faces in the world.<ref name="RockHall">{{cite web|url=https://rockhall.com/inductees/madonna/bio/|title=Madonna Biography|publisher=[[Rock and Roll Hall of Fame]]|year=2008|accessdate=April 15, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Marcovitz">{{Cite book|isbn=1604138599|title=Madonna: Entertainer (Women of Achievement) Library Binding – November 1, 2010|publisher=Amazon.com}}</ref><ref name="ESMT"/> Tetzlaff felt that "the power of the omnipresent Madonna has to do with [[hyperreality]], but an infinite accumulation of simulacra, an overabundance of information".<ref name="Claudeochoyocho">{{harvnb|Claude|2002|pp=88}}</ref> Journalist Quico Alsedo from ''[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]'' in Spain felt that Madonna has build a nation, landless but densely populated.<ref name="ElMundoNation">{{cite web|url=http://www.elmundo.es/blogs/elmundo/rockandblog/2013/09/05/madonna-bachar-el-asad.html|title=Madonna = Bachar El Asad|first=Alsedo|last=Quico|work=[[El Mundo (Spain)|El Mundo]]|location=Spain|date=September 5, 2013|accessdate=April 15, 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref> Music critic T. Cole Rachel, stated in 2015, that "there’s an approximate 100% probability that any living human over the age of, say, 25 has some sort of specific Madonna-related memory... Even if you aren’t a super fan—or even a fan at all—there’s no escaping Madonna. She is everywhere."<ref name="Pitchfork">{{cite web|url=http://pitchfork.com/features/interviews/9604-pop-sovereign-a-conversation-with-madonna/|title=Pop Sovereign: A Conversation with Madonna|work=[[Pitchfork Media]]|date=March 2, 2015|accessdate=April 15, 2015|author=T. Cole Rachel}}</ref>
In his book ''Madonna As Postmodern Myth'' (2002), French academic [[Georges Claude Guilbert]] explains how Madonna reflects today's society,<ref name="Claudenopage">{{harvnb|Claude|2002|pp=}}</ref> while William Langley from ''[[The Daily Telegraph]]'' feels that "Madonna has changed the world's [[social history]], has done more things as more different people than anyone else is ever likely to."<ref name="Telegraph">{{cite web|url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/newstopics/profiles/2530197/Madonna-mistress-of-metamorphosis.html|title=Madonna, mistress of metamorphosis|first=William|last=Langley|work=[[The Daily Telegraph]]|date=August 9, 2008|accessdate=April 13, 2015}}</ref> American poet [[Jane Miller]] compares her functions as an [[archetype]] directly inside contemporary culture with the [[Black Madonna]].<ref name="Benson">{{harvnb|Benson|2000|pp=241}}</ref> Professor John R. May concludes that Madonna is a contemporary "[[gesamtkunstwerk]]",<ref name="May">{{harvnb|May|1997|pp=169}}</ref> and academic [[Sergio Fajardo]] labels her "a very powerful [[symbol]]".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elmundo.com/portal/resultados/detalles/?idx=207402|trans-title=Fans waiting for Madonna|first=Giselle|last=Tatiana|first2=Rojas |last2=Pérez|work=[[El Mundo (Colombia)|ElMundo]]|location=Colombia|date=November 25, 2012|accessdate=April 13, 2015|language=Spanish|title=Fans esperan a Madonna}}</ref> Scholar Belén González Morales of the [[Autonomous University of Barcelona]] comments, "'The infinite dissection' of Madonna is like a body [[paradigmatic]] of the global age that emanating a tremendous amount of meanings ... Madonna has been become a [[cultural artifact]].<ref name="dissection">{{harvnb|Clúa Ginés|Pitarch|2008|pp=81,84,90}}</ref> [[Strawberry Saroyan]] states that she's a storyteller and a cultural pioneer, and emphasizes the important thing is her message: "And all of those things have been brilliantly of a piece. Madonna's ability to take her message beyond music and impact women's lives has been her legacy".<ref name="salon2000">{{cite news|title=So-called Chaos|work=Salon|author=[[Strawberry Saroyan]] and [[Michelle Goldberg]]|url=http://www.salon.com/2000/10/10/madonna_4/|date=October 10, 2000|accessdate=April 15, 2013}}</ref>
Authors note that Madonna has proved a master of [[cultural appropriation]].<ref name="Cleveland"/> She is also considered "a barometer of culture that directs the attention to cultural shifts, struggles and [[Transformation of culture|changes]]."<ref name="Kakutani"/> The [[American Library Association]], in a review of music journalist Adam Sexton's book ''Desperately Seeking Madonna: In Search of the Meaning of the World's Most Famous Woman'', remarks: "Love her or hate her, Madonna is an inescapable figure in the contemporary cultural landscape".<ref name="AdamSexton">{{Cite book|edition = 1st Printing January 1993|title = Desperately Seeking Madonna: In Search of the Meaning of the World's Most Famous Woman|publisher = Delta|date = December 1992|location = New York|isbn = 9780385306881|editor-first = Adam|editor-last = Sexton}}</ref> Musicologist [[Susan McClary]] suggests that Madonna is engaged in rewriting some very fundamental levels of Western thought.<ref name="john">{{harvnb|Shepard|2003|pp=108}}</ref> One academic from [[Lehigh University]] expressed that she stands behind all people and helps them fight against being ostracized in society.<ref name="Gaugler"/> Contribuitor from company [[Spin Media]] felt that "Madonna has changed society through her fiery ambition and unwillingness to compromise".<ref name="DeathandTaxes"/> Professor [[Karlene Faith]] accerted Madonna's peculiarity is that she has cruised so freely through so many cultural terrains. She has been a 'cult' figure within self-propelling [[subculture]]s just as she became a major". She also concluded that as fans, moral critics, media journalists, or university scholars, we mediate what Madonna means to our society.<ref name="Faith"/> In general, academic radicals turned Madonna into the "[[cottage industry]]", most notable in the 1990s.<ref name="Cullen85">{{harvnb|Cullen|2001|p=85}}</ref>
=== In United States === Madonna is part of the [[Culture of United States]] and an American icon. Authors in ''American Icons'' (2006) felt that "like [[Marilyn Monroe]], [[Elvis Presley]] or [[Coca-Cola]], Madonna image is immediately recognizable around the world and instantly communicates many of the values of U.S. culture".<ref name="HallUS">{{harvnb|Hall|2006|pp=51}}</ref> [[Rodrigo Fresán]] commented: "saying that Madonna just is a pop star is as inappropriate as saying that Coca-Cola is just a [[Soft drink|soda]]. Madonna is one of the classic symbols of [[Made in USA]]".<ref name="Fresan88">{{harvnb|Aguilar Guzmán|2010|pp=88}}</ref> She was included in the book ''100 Entertainers Who Changed America: An Encyclopedia of Pop Culture'' of [[Greenwood Publishing Group]]. Historian professor Glen Jeansonne, said that "Madonna freed Americans from their inhibitions and made them feel good about having fun".<ref name="Jeansonne">{{harvnb|Jeansonne|2006|pp=446}}</ref> Editor Erin Skarda from ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' felt that essentially redefined what it meant to be famous in America.<ref name="TimeFashionICon">{{Cite news|url=http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2110513_2110627_2110639,00.html|title=Madonna - All-TIME Top 100 Icons in Fashion, Style and Design|date=April 2, 2012|accessdate=June 17, 2015|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|first=Erin|last=Skarda}}</ref> Author in ''Shaded Lives: African-American Women and Television'' (2002), said that only Madonna rivaled the space [[Oprah Winfrey]] occupied in the late twentieth century and in the psyche of national culture.<ref name="Shaded">{{harvnb|Smith-Shomade|2002|p=162}}</ref> Karen Lac in her Madonna's biography concluded that she is one of those rare people who have become a part of American culture itself.<ref name="Lac">{{cite web|url=https://www.amazon.com/dp/B008R53QE2|title=Madonna: Biography of the World's Greatest Pop Singer [Kindle Edition]|accessdate=February 7, 2015|publisher=Amazon.com}}</ref> Jim Cullen wrote in ''Restless in the Promised Land: Catholics and the American Dream'' (2001) "few figures in [[American Dream|American life]] have manage to exert as much control over their destinies as she has, and the fact that se has done so as a woman is all the more remarkable. That Madonna has done this is indisputable".<ref>{{harvnb|Cullen|2001|p=86}}</ref>
In [[Society of the United States|American society]], she is often referenced by her sexual [[Feminist political theory|feminist political movement]]. For example, [[Sara Marcus]] from [[Salon (website)|Salon.com]] felt that with the height of her career, Madonna brought the changes to American culture and expressed that "her revelatory spreading of sexual liberation to [[Middle America (United States)|Middle America]], changed this country for the better. And that's not old news; we're still living it.... as we can see in everything from the ubiquity of pop stars to [[Rihanna]]'s career. She ends saying that "the woman [Madonna] remade American culture".<ref name="Salon">{{cite web|url=http://www.salon.com/2012/02/04/how_madonna_changed_america/|title=How Madonna liberated America|first=Sara|last=Marcus|work=[[Salon (website)|Salon]]|date=February 3, 2012|accessdate=April 13, 2015}}</ref> [[Andrew O'Hagan]] felt that "Madonna is like a heroic opponent of cultural and political authoritarianism of the American "[[The Establishment|establishment]]".<ref name="Claude">{{harvnb|Claude|2002|pp=41–43}}</ref> Cultural critic [[Annalee Newitz]] commented that Madonna has given to American culture, and culture throughout the world, is not a collection of songs; rather, it is a collection of images.<ref name="Newitz">{{cite news|url=http://bad.eserver.org/issues/1993/09/newitz.html|title=Madonna's Revenge|first=Newitz|last=Annalee|authorlink=Annalee Newitz|publisher=[[EServer.org]]|date=November 1993|accessdate=June 17, 2015}}</ref> ''[[USA Today]]'' dubbed her as "our lady of constant makeovers".<ref name=Cullen85 /> And [[Lynn Spigel]] wrote that Madonna intervened "America's notions of sex, gender and power. Madonna publicized her appropriation of the unspoken and taboo areas of Americas's moralist rhetoric and capitalized on it through the scandalization and titillation of the consumer".<ref name="Spiegel122">{{harvnb|Spigel|2007|pp=122}}</ref>
== Madonna as an icon == Dubbed as the most iconic female artist of all time,<ref name="WMA"/> Madonna is a synonym of vanguard in the fields of she work.<ref name="Moma">{{cite web|url=http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/espectaculos/86958.html|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203021938/http://www.eluniversal.com.mx/espectaculos/86958.html|title=Impone tendencia la 'Chica material'|trans-title=Imposes trend, the Material Girl|language=Spanish|location=Mexico|work=[[El Universal (Mexico City)|El Universal]]|archivedate=December 3, 2013 |date=November 2008|accessdate=June 22, 2015}}</ref> By her impact and contributions, she [[Bibliography of Madonna|has been analyzed]] from the point view of [[Madonna Studies|several studies]], including feminist, sexual, gay, [[Queer studies|queer]], musical, [[Social studies|social]] and [[postmodern]] etc., becoming known as an icon in all these branches. Reader editor Brian McNair wrote that "Madonna more than made up for in iconic status and cultural influence".<ref name="McNair">{{harvnb|McNair|2002|pp=69}}</ref> Professor Dennis Hall said that "the fact that not only her work but her person was open to multiple interpretations contributed to the rise of [[Madonna Studies]]".<ref name="Hall"/> As Hall, [[Hao Huang]] in his 1999 book ''Music in the 20th Century'' wrote that Madonna has made a career as well as an art out of reinventing herself — as a rock diva, stage and screen star, video vixen, fashion icon, and cultural phenomenon.<ref name="Huang">{{harvnb|Huang|1999|pp=386}}</ref>
[[File:Madonnaicon.jpg|thumb|left|Icon of Madonna, taken in 1990 at the [[AIDS Project Los Angeles]]. Is created by [[Alan Light]].]] Academics felt that [[Oxford English Dictionary]]'s recent definition of "icon" as a "person or thing" or an "institution", etc., considered worthy of admiration or respect or "regarded as a representative symbol", esp. of a culture or movement” (OED 2009), and this include Madonna.<ref name="Heindelber University"/> Alyson Welsh from ''[[The Guardian]]'' commented that "she is an amazing role model, and a [[cultural icon]]".<ref name="GuardianWels">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/fashion/2015/apr/09/why-madonna-is-still-my-style-icon-despite-the-look-at-me-lingerie|title=Why Madonna is still my style icon (despite the look-at-me lingerie)|work=[[The Guardian]]|date=April 9, 2015|accessdate=June 17, 2015|first=Alyson|last=Welsh}}</ref> The program [[Australasian Journal of American Studies]] (AJAS) remember that it's not an accident that [[Mickey Mouse]] and Madonna are worldwide icons.<ref name="AJAS">{{cite journal|title=AJAS|date=July 1, 1996|accessdate=June 18, 2015|volume=15|work=[[Australasian Journal of American Studies]] (AJAS)|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=oelKAAAAYAAJ&q=It's+not+an+accident+that+Mickey+Mouse+and+Madonna+are+worldwide+icons&dq=It's+not+an+accident+that+Mickey+Mouse+and+Madonna+are+worldwide+icons&hl=es-419&sa=X&ei=22CDVc20GcGz-AGc14K4CA&ved=0CBYQ6AEwAQ|page=60|ref=harv}}</ref>
Professors from [[Heidelberg University]] shows how Madonna's "iconicity" is indeed that of a "meta-icon" in the sense that the self-reflexive imitation of celebrity poses. Calls this strategy "iconizing", in analogy to the concept of "vogueing". The essay also inquires into the blend of biography and performativity that can be said to underlie Madonna's "iconizing" in relation to the performance artists.<ref name="Heindelber University">{{cite web|url=http://www.as.uni-heidelberg.de/personen/Leypoldt/files/LeypoldtEnglerAmericanCulturalIconsIntroduction.pdf|title=Cultural Icons, Charismatic Heroes, Representative Lives|publisher=[[Heidelberg University]]|accessdate=June 17, 2015|page=22}}</ref> [[Michelle Goldberg]] said that "[[Andy Warhol]] did an enormous amount to change that idea in highbrow circles, but Madonna made it conventional wisdom to conflate art and commerce. She pioneered this kind of multimedia, 'life as performance art'."<ref name="salon2000"/>
Before closing the 20th century, ''[[Q (magazine)|Q]]'' magazine declared her as one of the most important cultural figures of this century.<ref name="cultural icon">{{cite journal|last=Wexter|first=Erica|title=Reviews Madonna Ray of Light|date=April 1998|accessdate=April 7, 2013|volume=21|issue=3|work=ThirdWay|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h56sBy_z9eUC&pg=PA28|page=28|ref=harv}}</ref> [[Miranda Sawyer]], [[Jefferson Hack]] and others authors called to her as a 21st-century icon.<ref name="Sawyer">{{Cite book|isbn=0752890514|title=Madonna|publisher=Amazon.com}}</ref><ref name="Hack">{{cite web|url=http://www.dazeddigital.com/music/article/21252/1/madonna-21st-century-icon|title=Madonna: 21st Century Icon|first=Jefferson|authorlink=Jefferson Hack|last=Hack|work=[[Dazed]]|year=2008|accessdate=June 20, 2015}}</ref> [[Andrew Morton (writer)|Andrew Morton]] wrote in his book ''[[Madonna (book)|Madonna]]'' (2002) that "she is the undisputed female icon of the [[modern age]]". Also cited as one of the most fascinating women and enigmatic in [[current history]].<ref name="Morton">{{Cite book|isbn=1854794329|title=Madonna Paperback – March 27, 2002|publisher=Amazon.com}}</ref> ''[[Madonna in Art]]'' (2004) is a book by Mem Mehmet where included the work art by over a hundred artists, including [[Andrew Logan]], [[Sebastian Krüger]], [[Al Hirschfeld]], and [[Peter Howson]]. The book is a testament to her unique global impact.<ref name="Mehmet">{{Cite book|isbn=1904957005|title=Madonna in Art Hardcover – December 1, 2004|publisher=Amazon.com}}</ref> French biographer Anne Bleuzen wrote that she is "interplanetary",<ref name="Bleuzen">{{Cite book|title=Madonna Belle reliure – 18 novembre 2005|publisher=Amazon.com|isbn=2915957037}}</ref> and Italian author [[Francesco Falconi]] felt that she is an icon eternal.<ref name="ReginadelPop">{{Cite book|isbn=8876155503|title=Mad for Madonna. La regina del pop (Italian) Perfect Paperback – January 1, 2011|publisher=Amazon.com}}</ref> Editor Eduardo Gutiérrez Seguro from Latin magazine ''[[CNN Expansión|Quién]]'' wrote:
{{Quote|Her Majesty: music and pop culture would not be the same [without Madonna]. Madonna set a precedent never seen for a singer, before her, [[eroticism]] was not a ''must''—per very disguised form it takes, in the scenes videos or lyrics—. Feminism underwent a complete makeover and the formula surprise/offense the public has she placed in the Everest of show business.<ref name="Quien">{{cite web|url=http://www.quien.com/espectaculos/2012/02/06/su-majestad-camaleonica-madonna|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131203021938/http://www.quien.com/espectaculos/2012/02/06/su-majestad-camaleonica-madonna|title=Su majestad camaleónica: Madonna|trans-title=Her Majesty chameleonic: Madonna|language=Spanish|work=[[CNN Expansión|Quién]]|archivedate=December 3, 2013 |date=February 6, 2012|accessdate=June 23, 2015|first=Eduardo|last=Gutiérrez Seguro}}</ref>}}
=== Music === [[File:Madonna platinum record 2.png|thumb|upright|A platinum record for her album ''[[GHV2]]'' under [[Maverick Records]].]]
''[[Rolling Stone]]'' described her as a musical icon without peer,<ref name="Queenofpopalltime">{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/pictures/readers-poll-the-queen-of-pop-20110706/1-madonna-0325148|title=At 50, has Madonna surpassed the Beatles?|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|date=July 6, 2011|accessdate=June 16, 2015}}</ref> while [[RTL Television]] Belgium said that "Madonna is a key figure in the music".<ref name="RTL">{{cite web|url=http://www.rtl.be/people/people/news/722985/apres-30-ans-de-carriere-madonna-cartonne-toujours|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130517190045/http://www.rtl.be/people/people/news/722985/apres-30-ans-de-carriere-madonna-cartonne-toujours|title=A presque 30 ans de carrière, Madonna cartonne toujours|publisher=[[RTL Television]] ([[RTL Group]])|location=Belgium|archivedate=May 17, 2013|accessdate=June 22, 2015|date=March 21, 2013|language=French}}</ref> Bill Wyman, editor of ''[[Chicago Reader]]'', wrote that she is a "genuinely freakish figure in popular music".<ref name="ChicagoReader">{{cite web|url=http://acculturated.com/madonna-should-not-have-apologized/|title=Truth or Dare: Madonna's big lie|first=Bill|last=Wyman|work=[[Chicago Reader]]|publisher=[[Wrapports]]|date=June 20, 1991|accessdate=June 17, 2015}}</ref> According to international media and critics, Madonna is the most influential female recording artist of all time,<ref name="WMA"/><ref name="cnn2008">{{cite news|first= Stephanie |last= Busari |title=Hey Madonna, Don't Give Up the Day Job!|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2008/SHOWBIZ/Movies/03/18/madonna.movies/?iref=mpstoryview|publisher=CNN|date=March 24, 2008|accessdate=April 11, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Blackmore">{{harvnb|Blackmore|de Castro|2008|p=496}}</ref> and the greatest woman in music history.<ref name="Jojo">{{harvnb|Regalado|2002|pp=11}}</ref><ref name="VH1Woman">{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1679384/madonna-music-greatest-woman/|title=Madonna Crowned ‘Greatest’ Woman In Music|date=February 12, 2012|accessdate=June 18, 2015|publisher=MTV}}</ref>
Her contributions on music are generally praised by critics, which have also been known to induce controversy. Tony Sclafani from company [[MSNBC]] felt that her Madonna’s impact and effect on the future direction of music bests [[The Beatles]], even that quarter century after Madonna emerged, artists still use her ideas and seem modern and edgy doing so.<ref name="MSNBC">{{cite web|url=http://www.today.com/id/26164523/ns/today-today_entertainment/t/has-madonna-surpassed-beatles/|title=At 50, has Madonna surpassed the Beatles?|first=Tony|last=Sclafani|publisher=[[MSNBC]]|date=December 8, 2008|accessdate=April 14, 2015}}</ref> Laura Barcella in her book ''Madonna and Me: Women Writers on the Queen of Pop'' (2012) wrote that "really, Madonna changed everything the musical landscape, the '80s look ''[[du jour]]'', and most significantly, what a mainstream female pop star could (and couldn't) say, do, or accomplish in the public eye."<ref name="Barcella">{{harvnb|Barcella|2012|pp=}}</ref> Similar to Barcella, Joe Levy ''[[Blender (magazine)|Blender]]'' editor in chief, "opened the door for what women could achieve and were permitted to do".<ref name="USAToday">{{cite web|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/life/music/news/2008-08-14-madonna_N.htm|title=Pop icons at 50: Madonna|first=Edna|last=Gundersen|authorlink=Edna Gundersen|work=[[USA Today]]|date=August 17, 2008|accessdate=June 13, 2015}}</ref>
In the [[music industry]], Madonna was the first female to have complete control of her music and image.<ref name="100artist">{{cite web|url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/lists/100-greatest-artists-of-all-time-19691231/madonna-20110420|title=100 Greatest Artists: Madonna|accessdate=April 10, 2015|work=[[Rolling Stone]]}}</ref><ref name="MTVBio">{{cite web|url=http://www.mtv.com/artists/madonna/|title=Madonna Biography at MTV|author=[[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]]|accessdate=April 10, 2015|publisher=MTV}}</ref> Authors noted that before Madonna, [[record label|records labels]] determined every step of artists, but she introduced her style and conceptually directed every part of her career; the music industry was the foundation to permanently change the way the record companies treat artists.<ref name="Batanga"/> Journalist Carol Benson wrote that Madonna entered the music business with definite ideas about her image, but it was her track record that enabled her to increase her level of creative control over her music.<ref name="Benson31">{{harvnb|Benson|2000|pp=231}}</ref> Many years after, she founded [[Maverick Records]] became the most successful "[[vanity label]]" in the [[history of music]]. While under Madonna's control it generated well over $1 billion for [[Warner Bros. Records]], more money than any other recording artist's [[record label]].<ref name="Spin">{{cite journal|title=Hush Hush / The Monthly Dish On The Music Business|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FD4jKFVQOhMC&pg=PA58&lpg=PA58&dq=Maverick+Records+became+the+most+successful+vanity+label+in+the+history+of+music&source=bl&ots=DSbCJujpEh&sig=d1c_YvuqZdqCyextGE0xddh-r0Y&hl=es&sa=X&ei=hMgZVb6IEMXWUdiMgIAE&ved=0CEsQ6AEwBQ#v=onepage&q=Maverick%20Records%20became%20the%20most%20successful%20vanity%20label%20in%20the%20history%20of%20music&f=false|first=Joe|last=Fleischer|date=October 1998|accessdate=March 30, 2015|work=[[Spin (magazine)|Spin]]|publisher=[[SpinMedia]]|issn=0886-3032|volume=14|issue=10|page=58}}</ref><ref name="KeyAchi">{{cite web|url=http://www.marqueecapital.com/key_achievements.php|title=Madonna Key Achievements|accessdate=March 30, 2015|publisher=Marquee Capital}}</ref>
Critics felt in retrospect that Madonna's presence is defined for changing [[Popular music|contemporary music]] [[History of music|history]] for women's, mainly [[Rock music|rock]], [[Dance music|dance]] and [[Pop music|pop]] scene.<ref name="DeathandTaxes"/><ref name="MSNBC"/><ref name="Barcella" /><ref name="Vh1">{{cite news|url=http://www.vh1.com/music/tuner/2014-11-12/madonna-like-a-virgin-30th-anniversary/2/|title=10 Things Millennials Don’t Understand About Madonna|publisher=[[VH1]]|first=Chris|last=Rosa|date=November 12, 2014|accessdate=June 16, 2015|pages=1–4}}</ref><ref name="Kaplan">{{harvnb|Kaplan|2012|p=32|quote=Madonna chaged the way pop music thought of women}}</ref><ref name="FormanBrunell">{{harvnb|Forman-Brunell|2001|p=531|quote=Madonna changed the face of popular music by bringing glimpses of feminism to maistream adiences}}</ref><ref name="RSS">{{cite web|url=http://rollingstone.es/specials/view/mujeres-que-cambiaron-las-reglas-del-rock|title=Mujeres que cambiaron las reglas del rock|work=[[Rolling Stone]]|location=Spain|trans-title=Woman who change the rock rules|accessdate=March 27, 2015|date=April 14, 2012|language=Spanish|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131110210540/http://rollingstone.es/specials/view/mujeres-que-cambiaron-las-reglas-del-rock|archivedate=November 10, 2013}}</ref> Also, she is cited that open the doors for the future [[hip-hop]] explosion and approach to sex to her music.<ref name="MSNBC"/> Erin Vargo from online magazine in popular culture, felt that "Madonna has fought for freedom of expression by female artists. Her legacy has paved the way for today’s pop, hip-hop, and rock artists to get into their own groove".<ref name="ACCULTURATED">{{cite web|url=http://acculturated.com/madonna-should-not-have-apologized/|title=Madonna Should Not Have Apologized|first=Erin|last=Vargo|publisher=[[Acculturated]]|date=January 9, 2015|accessdate=June 13, 2015}}</ref> ''[[The Times]]'' stated: "Madonna, whether you like her or not, started a revolution amongst women in music ... === Pop star === {{Quote box|align=left|width=30%|quote="Madonna’s influence reigns supreme on today’s artists, her impact on pop culture through film and fashion may never be topped, and Madonna changed the role of women in pop music. Academic Becca Cragin explain that "Madonna has managed to hold the public's attention for 30 years now, in large part because of her skillful use of the visual in expressing herself and marketing her music".<ref name="Cleveland"/> French academic Georges-Claudes Guillbert wrote that taking some elements and transforms them into commercial products. 1995), agree that Madonna is "the world's greatest artist" while others classify her as "the most powerful celebrity or famous woman in the world".<ref name="AdamSexton"/><ref name="RettenmundBook">{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=rplwQgAACAAJ|title=Encyclopedia Madonnica|accessdate=February 22, 2015|quote= [[Norman Mailer]] thinks she's our "greatest living female artist." === Mainstream === {{See also|Records and achievements of Madonna}}
[[File:Madonna Frozen painting.jpg|thumb|A painting inspired by Madonna's look on the music video of "[[Frozen (Madonna song)|Frozen]]". The released of ''[[Ray of Light]]'' increased the popularity of traditional [[Culture of Asia|Asian culture]] in American popular culture.]]
Called to as a "mainstream hero" by professor [[Karlene Faith]],<ref name="Faith">{{cite journal|jstor=103138/j.ctt2tv4xw#|title=Madonna, Bawdy & Soul}}</ref> Madonna is [[List of best-selling music artists|the best-selling woman artist in the history]],<ref name="WMA"/> and the most successful female recording artist of alltime certified by ''[[Guinness Book of Worlds Records]]''.<ref name="mostsuccessful">{{cite web|url=http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/content_pages/record.asp?recordid=55387 |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20040904205619/http://www.guinnessworldrecords.com/content_pages/record.asp?recordid=55387|title=Most Successful Female Solo Artist|editor=[[Craig Glenday]]|work=[[Guinness Book of World Records]]|archivedate=September 4, 2004 |accessdate=April 13, 2015}}</ref> With several critics feeling that she paved the way for every female artist,<ref name="Vh1"/> ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine expressed that "every pop star of the last two or three decades has Madonna to thank in some part for his or her success".<ref name="Time">{{cite news|url=http://content.time.com/time/specials/packages/article/0,28804,2029774_2029776_2031853,00.html|title=The 25 Most Powerful Women of the Past Century|work=[[Time (magazine)|Time]]|first=Michelle|last=Castillo|date=November 18, 2010|accessdate=June 16, 2015}}</ref> She is cited like an influence by [[List of artists influenced by Madonna|many other artists worldwide]].
Her [[Super star|superstardom]] also is cited as the motivation of the success commercial and popularised or introduction of several things like branches, terms, groups, cultures, persons and products. For example, the media cited her acting in the movie ''[[Evita (1996 film)|Evita]]'', that popularised Argentinian politics and she put the nation [[Malawi]] on the map while she launched the trend for celebrity adoption.<ref name="WMA">{{cite web|url=http://www.worldmusicawards.com/index.php/news/how-madonna-changed-world/|title=How Madonna changed the World!|publisher=[[World Music Awards]]|date=August 13, 2013|accessdate=June 15, 2015}}</ref><ref name="Mirror"/> Madonna's success open to other celebrities such as singers, actors and politicians have successfully dabbling in the publishing field for [[Children literature|young audiences]].<ref name="TheGuardian">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/books/2006/nov/03/booksforchildrenandteenagers.familyandrelationships|title=Once upon a time|date=November 3, 2006|accessdate=June 18, 2015|work=The Guardian|first=Ed|last=Pilkington}}</ref> Her first book ''[[Sex (book)|Sex]]'' changed publishing history.<ref name="MarkBlankenship">{{cite web|url=http://www.newnownext.com/madonna-sex-boo/10/2012/|title=My Weird Journey With Madonna’s ‘Sex’ Book|date=October 22, 2012|accessdate=April 8, 2015|publisher=[[Logo TV|NewNowNext.com]]|authorlink=Mark Blankenship|first=Mark|last=Blankenship}}</ref> Her album ''[[Something to Remember]]'' set a trend of releasing ballad albums afterward, such as the 1996 albums ''[[Love Songs (Elton John album)|Love Songs]]'' by [[Elton John]] and ''[[If We Fall in Love Tonight]]'' by [[Rod Stewart]].<ref>{{cite journal|title=New Sets Offer 'Greatest Ballads'|first=David|last=Sprague|work=Billboard|issn=0006-2510|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ugkEAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA15#v=onepage&q&f=false|page=15|accessdate=April 6, 2015}}</ref>
She popularizing the [[Vogue (dance)|Voguing]]. Academic Stepehn Ursprung from [[Smith College]] felt that "Madonna created a market for Voguing in the commercial entertainment world". Analyzed that "through a close connection with the continued commercial success of Madonna, Voguing has left its mark on the world largely... Voguing was first appropriated by pop culture by pop music icon Madonna".<ref name="Smith">{{cite web|url=http://sophia.smith.edu/blog/danceglobalization/2012/05/01/voguing-madonna-and-cyclical-reappropriation/|title=Voguing: Madonna and Cyclical Reappropriation|publisher=[[Smith College]]|date=May 1, 2012|accessdate=June 18, 2015|first=Stephen|last=Ursprung}}</ref> The website Wallblog ([[Haymarket Media Group]]) from United Kingdom called tentatively in a question, to [[Yahoo!]] like the "Madonna of digital media".<ref name="Wall">{{cite web|url=http://wallblog.co.uk/2013/05/31/is-yahoo-the-madonna-of-digital-media/|title=Is Yahoo the Madonna of digital media?|publisher=Wallblog ([[Haymarket Media Group]])|location=United Kingdom|date=May 31, 2013|last=Kane|first=Same|accessdate=June 18, 2015}}</ref> Even, is cited that she has carried the [[burlesque]] to [[mass culture]].<ref name="Totem"/> As is cited that MTV helped her, some authors like Josue Rich from ''[[Entertainment Weekly]]'' felt that Madonna helped make [[MTV]] (alongside [[Michael Jackson]]).<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.ew.com/ew/article/0,,285759,00.html|title=Madonna Banned|author=Joshua Rich|work=[[Entertainment Weekly]]|date=November 20, 1998|accessdate=March 14, 2013|quote=Madonna helped make MTV ''as much as [MTV] helped make her,'' says Mark Bego, author of Madonna: Blonde Ambition..}}</ref> Biographer Mick St Michael wrote that "[[girl power]] began with Madonna".<ref name="90Mick">{{Cite book|isbn=0711977348|title=Madonna: In Her Own Words (In Their Own Words) Paperback – December 31, 1990|publisher=Amazon.com}}</ref> Also, she has credit for the introduction of [[electronic music]] to the stage of [[popular music]],<ref name="ROL">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/song/ray-of-light-mt0004973231|title=Ray of Light - Madonna|publisher=Allmusic. Rovi Corporation|first=Liana|last=Jonas|accessdate=June 18, 2015}}</ref> and innovated the [[rave]] culture.<ref name="OBrien">{{harvnb|O'Brien|2002|pp=485–489}}</ref><ref name="Harrison">{{harvnb|Harrison|2011|p=4}}</ref> Similar, music critic [[Stephen Thomas Erlewine]] felt that Madonna introduced the dance pop to mainstream scene.<ref name="MadonnaReview">{{cite web|url=http://www.allmusic.com/album/madonna-mw0000268192|title=Madonna - Madonna review|publisher=Allmusic. Rovi Corporation|authorlink=Stephen Thomas Erlewine|first=Stephen Thomas|last=Erlewine|accessdate=June 20, 2015}}</ref>
According to intellectuals, the phenomenon of femininity inspired by [[South Asia]] as a tendency in Western media could go back to February 1998 when the pop icon Madonna released her video for "[[Frozen (Madonna song)|Frozen]]". They explained that "although Madonna did not initiate the Indian fashion accessories beauty [...] took the public eye to attract the attention of the global media.<ref name="Hammer">{{harvnb|Hammer|Kellner|2009|pp=502–503}}</ref> The Spanish style of Madonna in the video "[[La Isla Bonita]]" became popular and was reflected in fashion trends of the time in the form of "boleros", skirts with tables and rosaries and crucifixes as accessories.<ref name="Clerk">{{harvnb|Clerk|2002|p=44}}</ref> According to the official website of the city [[Safed]], Madonna popularized the [[Jewish mysticism]].<ref name="Safed">{{cite web|url=http://www.safed.co.il/city-of-kabbalah-html|title=Tzfat, The City of Kabbalah|publisher=[[Safed]]|accessdate=June 18, 2015}}</ref> Madonna set a trend that influenced people to take interest in the sexuality of women's bodies.<ref name="ImpactYahoo">{{cite web|url=http://www.ukessays.co.uk/essays/history/the-cultural-significance-of-madonna.php|title=The cultural significance of Madonna|work=UK Essays|date=August 5, 2005|accessdate=June 18, 2015}}</ref>{{unreliable source?|date=October 2015}} In general, some authors like entertainment critic Rogelio Segoviano felt that "the fever for queen of pop does not yield to the passage of time".<ref name="ElUniversal">{{cite web |url=http://www.domingoeluniversal.mx/historias/detalle/Todos+quieren+con+Madonna-1070 |title=TODOS QUIEREN CON MADONNA |trans-title=Everybody wants with Madonna |first=Segoviano |last=Rogelio |work=[[El Universal (Mexico City)|El Universal]] |location=Mexico |date=November 18, 2012 |accessdate=April 15, 2015 |language=Spanish |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150223224203/http://www.domingoeluniversal.mx/historias/detalle/Todos%2Bquieren%2Bcon%2BMadonna-1070 |archivedate=February 23, 2015 |df=mdy }}</ref>
=== Fashion === [[File:Madonna's Blond Ambition Corset.jpg|left|thumb|upright|Iconic corset made by fashion designer [[Jean Paul Gaultier]] that Madonna wore during her 1990 [[Blond Ambition World Tour]].]]
''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' included her as one of the Top 100 Icons of all time in fashion, style and design.<ref name="TimeFashionICon"/> Critics praised Madonna's style during her career, which became the defining look in the 80s.<ref name="Mirror">{{cite web|url=https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/madonnas-55th-birthday-55-ways-2175047|title=Happy 55th Birthday Madonna! Here are 55 ways you changed the world|first=Kate|last=Wills|work=[[Daily Mirror]]|date=August 16, 2013|accessdate=June 15, 2015}}</ref> This gave rise to the term of [[Madonna wannabe]]. To experts in the 1990s, her use of fashion was even more eclectic.<ref name="Oh">{{harvnb|Benstock|Ferriss|1994|p=172}}</ref>
Journalist Michael Pye felt that "the face that launched a thousand fashions. To a large extent Madonna not only makes fashion, she is fashion.<ref name="Claude37">{{harvnb|Claude|2002|pp=37}}</ref> Editor of ''[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]'' magazine [[Anna Wintour]] declared: {{Quote|She's a perfect example of how popular culture and street style now influence the world of fashion. Over the years, Madonna has been one of the most potent style setters of our time. She, just as much as [[Karl Lagerfeld]], makes fashion happen.<ref name="Claude37"/>|sign=|source=}}
Professors in ''Oh Fashion'' (1994) book wrote that "the Madonna phenomenon suggests that in a postmodern image culture identity is constructed through image and fashion, involving one's look, pose, and attitude. Fashion and identity for Madonna are inseparable from her aesthetic practices, from her cultivation of her image in her music videos, films, TV appearances, concerts, and other cultural interventions".<ref name="Oh2">{{harvnb|Benstock|Ferriss|1994|p=176}}</ref> ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' declared that "no pop diva has reinvented her fashion image with the consistency and creativity of Madonna... she evolved into a fashion-forward icon whose sense of style became as influential as her chart-topping tunes".<ref name="BillboardFashion">{{cite web|url=http://www.billboard.com/photos/428558/madonnas-fashion-evolution-her-most-iconic-looks|title=Madonna's Fashion Evolution: Her Most Iconic Looks|work=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]|date=March 22, 2012|accessdate=June 15, 2015}}</ref> Similarly, editor of ''[[The Huffington Post]]'' Dana Oliver comments why Madonna is the ultimate style chameleon and added that "no one has transformed herself like Madonna. She has had about as many looks as she has records. Her ability to constantly reinvent herself and her music has helped to secure her status as an icon, and she has influenced a generation of copycats. In short, no one has had more diverse looks than Madonna".<ref name="THP">{{cite web|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/2014/08/15/madonna-style-transformation-photos_n_3763575.html|title=Why Madonna Is The Ultimate Style Chameleon|work=[[HuffPost]]|date=August 16, 2013|accessdate=June 19, 2015|last=Oliver|first=Dana}}</ref>
Chloe Wyma from [[Louise Blouin Media]] commented that Madonna's chameleon attitude in transforming her fashion has become a universally recognized fact.<ref name="Blouin">{{cite web|url=http://mx.blouinartinfo.com/news/story/950144/madonna-a-los-55-anos-de-edad-existe-otro-momento-mejor-para|title=Madonna a los 55 años de edad: ¿existe otro momento mejor para examinar sus contribuciones a la moda y el feminismo?|trans-title=Madonna to 55 years: Is there another better moment to examine her contributions to fashion and feminism?|accessdate=June 10, 2015|publisher=[[Louise Blouin Media]]|first= Wyma|last=Chloe|language=Spanish}}</ref> Ana Laglere from [[Batanga Media]] expressed that "each new Madonna's style is a trend and is used by major designers as inspiration, flooding our world with innovative ideas".<ref name="Batanga">{{cite web|url=http://musica.batanga.com/9637/9-razones-que-explican-por-que-madonna-es-la-reina-del-pop-de-todos-los-tiempos|title=9 razones que explican por qué Madonna es la Reina del Pop de todos los tiempos|trans-title=9 reasons explain why Madonna is the Queen of Pop of all time|first=Laglere|last=Ana|publisher=[[Batanga Media|Batanga.com]]|date=April 14, 2015|accessdate=June 10, 2015|language=Spanish|pages=1–8}}</ref> Cynthia Robins from ''[[San Francisco Chronicle]]'' said that "when Madonna came along, all fashion hell broke loose. Thus far, her influence on fashion —high, low and otherwise— has transmogrified from 'Who's That Girl?' to what in the world will Madonna wear next?".<ref name="SF">{{cite web|url=http://www.sfgate.com/entertainment/article/The-Material-Girl-Madonna-s-fashion-sense-has-2882599.php|title=The Material Girl Madonna's fashion sense has|first=Cynthia|last=Robins|work=[[San Francisco Chronicle]]|date=September 2, 2001|accessdate=June 18, 2015}}</ref> Alessandra Codinha from ''Vogue'' named as "the master of reinvention".<ref name="VogueM">{{cite web|url=http://www.vogue.com/13253338/madonna-ghosttown-music-video-look/|title=Exclusive! Madonna on the Look of Her New Ghosttown video|first=Alessandra|last=Codinha|work=[[Vogue (magazine)|Vogue]]|date=April 7, 2015|accessdate=June 18, 2015}}</ref>
=== Feminism === Madonna as a feminist icon has generated variety of opinions worldwide. She is frequently associated with the [[feminist movement]] and she is considered a revolutionary figure who questioned the boundaries of gender. She is also responsible for influencing the mentality and behavior of women and how society interprets these changes.<ref name="Batanga"/> Professor [[Sut Jhally]] felt that "Madonna is as an almost sacred feminist icon".<ref name="Sut Jhally">{{harvnb|Jhally|2006|p=194}}</ref> Academic [[Camille Paglia]] from [[University of the Arts (Philadelphia)|University of the Arts]] called Madonna a "true feminist" and noted that "she exposes the puritanism and suffocating ideology of [[American feminism]], which is stuck in an adolescent whining mode". According to her, "Madonna has taught young women to be fully female and sexual while still exercising total control over their lives".<ref name="Paglia">{{cite news|last=Paglia|first=Camille|authorlink=Camille Paglia|title=Madonna – Finally, A Real Feminist|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1990/12/14/opinion/madonna-finally-a-real-feminist.html|accessdate=June 17, 2015|newspaper=[[The New York Times]]|date=December 14, 1990}}</ref> Psychologist Jule Eisenbud in ''Sex Symbols'' (1999) noted that Madonna's refusal to accept that power and femininity is equivalent to masculinity has allowed her to maintain her status as a sex symbol.<ref name="Eisenbud">{{harvnb|Eisenbud|Leigh-Kile|1999|p=15}}</ref>
[[Jessica Valenti]] wrote in her book ''[[Madonna and Me: Women Writers on the Queen of Pop]]'' (2012) "sure, one [[Mary (mother of Jesus)|Madonna]] gave birth to Jesus... but our Madonna gave birth to "femme-inism".<ref name="Barcella2">{{Cite book|isbn=1593764294|title=Madonna and Me: Women Writers on the Queen of Pop Paperback – March 6, 2012|publisher=Amazon.com}}</ref> Spanish newspaper ''[[Periódico Diagonal]]'' convened a researchers panel discussion her as a feminist icon.<ref name="Totem">{{cite web|url=https://www.diagonalperiodico.net/culturas/madonna-icono-feminista-o-totem-consumista.html|title=Madonna: ¿icono feminista o tótem consumista?|author=Victor Lenore & Irene G. Rubio|work=[[Periódico Diagonal]]|trans-title=Madonna: feminist icon or consumerist totem?|date=June 26, 2012|accessdate=June 18, 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref> One of the comments, included that "she democratized the idea of women as protagonists and as agents of their own action", while some ambiguous ones stated that she contributed to women's empowerment of a few Western women, straight and gay middle class, but that empowerment is not feminism, because it is individualistic. Madonna was included in ''[[The Guardian]]'' list of the Top 100 women and editor Homa Khaleeli declared "no matter the decade or the fashion, she has always been frank about her toughness and ambition". She is still one of the most famous women on the planet and "she inspires not because she gives other women a helping hand, but because she breaks the boundaries of what's considered acceptable for women".<ref name="QReinvention">{{cite web|url=https://www.theguardian.com/culture/2011/mar/08/madonna-100-women|title=Madonna |date=March 8, 2011|accessdate=June 18, 2015|work=The Guardian|first=Homa|last=Khaleeli}}</ref> She was also included in ''[[Time (magazine)|Time]]'' magazine's list of the 25 most powerful women in the 20th century.<ref name="Time"/>
=== Sex symbol === Madonna has been referred to as a sexual icon,<ref name="Shaded">{{harvnb|Smith-Shomade|2002|p=162}}</ref><ref name="Sex icon">{{cite news|title=Madonna|url=http://newint.org/features/1991/08/05/reviews/|accessdate=June 17, 2015|newspaper=[[New Internationalist]]|date=August 5, 1991}}</ref> and [[sex symbol]]; most notable in the decade of the 1980s and 1990s.<ref name="Various">{{harvnb|Gregg|McDonogh|Wong||p=}}</ref> Also, she is cited as an icon of sexual freedom and expression.<ref name="ReginadelPop"/> Author Courtney E. Smith in the 2011 book ''Record Collecting for Girls'' noted that most people associate Madonna with sex.<ref name="SmithGaga">{{harvnb|Smith|2011|pp=119}}</ref> [[Chuck Klosterman]] in his book ''[[Sex, Drugs, and Cocoa Puffs]]'' (2003) wrote that "whenever I hear intellectuals talk about sexual icons of the present day, the name mentioned most is Madonna".<ref name="Chris">{{harvnb|Klosterman|2003|p=}}</ref> Even, Karen Fredericks from socialist newspaper ''[[Green Left Weekly]]'' in comment with her sexual attitude said that Madonna capturing an enormous mainstream audience, has had a perhaps surprising impact in progressive circles.<ref name="GreenLeftWeekly">{{cite news|url=https://www.greenleft.org.au/node/2766|title=and ain't i a woman?: Madonna: sexual revolutionary?|work=[[Green Left Weekly]]|last=Fredericks|first=Karen|date=October 22, 1992|issue=77|accessdate=June 18, 2015}}</ref>
Artists Adam Geczy and Vicki Karaminas in ''Queer Style'' (2013) noted Madonna transmogrified from virgin to dominatrix to ''Über Fran'', each time achieving iconic status. Added Madonna was the first woman to do so-and with mainstream panache and approbation.<ref name="Shaded2">{{harvnb|Geczy|Karaminas|2013|p=38}}</ref> [[bell hooks]] teach that her "power to the pussy" credo worked only to solidify Madonna's positioning on the backs of the marginalized. The sexual icon she constructed may indeed, then, accord power to the pussy.<ref name="Shaded2"/> Academics from [[European School of Management and Technology]] felt that Madonna became one of the world's first performers to manipulate the juxtaposition of sexual and religious themes.<ref name="ESMT">{{cite news|url=http://www.esmt.org/fm/13/Madonna_article.pdf|title=Madonna – Strategy on the Dance Floor|publisher=[[European School of Management and Technology]] (ESMT)|year=2006|author=Jaime Anderson & Martin Kupp|accessdate=June 18, 2015|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150529022945/http://www.esmt.org/fm/13/Madonna_article.pdf|archivedate=May 29, 2015|df=mdy-all}}</ref> American editor [[Janice Min]] wrote that "long before ''[[Sex and the City]]'', Madonna owned her sexuality. She made people cringe but also think differently about female performers. Her role as a provocateur changed boundaries for ensuing generations. She was a one-woman reality show."<ref name="USAToday"/> As Min, Shmuel Boteach, author of ''Hating Women'' (2005), felt that Madonna was largely responsible for erasing the line between music and pornography. He stated: "Before Madonna, it was possible for women more famous for their voices than their cleavage to emerge as music superstars. But in the post-Madonna universe, even highly original performers such as [[Janet Jackson]] now feel the pressure to expose their bodies on national television to sell albums".<ref>{{harvnb|Boteach|2005|p=110}}</ref>
During her career, Madonna has several provocative works. Perhaps, her book ''[[Sex (book)|Sex]]'' is most notorious, considered by many as the artist's most controversial and transgressive period.<ref name="Cambio">{{cite web|url=http://www.cambio.com.co/entretenimientocambio/791/ARTICULO-WEB-NOTA_INTERIOR_CAMBIO-4470108.html|title=Madonna, vigente a los 50|date=November 2, 2008|accessdate=February 21, 2013|language=Spanish|trans-title=Madonna, still got it at 50|publisher=Cambio.com ([[AOL]])|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130515143201/http://www.cambio.com.co/entretenimientocambio/791/ARTICULO-WEB-NOTA_INTERIOR_CAMBIO-4470108.html|archivedate=May 15, 2013|df=mdy-all}}</ref> Some authors noted that ''Sex'' helped Madonna make a name in the [[porn industry]],<ref name="Kirk Davidson"/> and earned her the title of [[Sadomasochism|S&M]]'s first [[cultural ambassador]].<ref name="Nyissue SM">{{cite journal|date=November 18, 1994|title=S&M offers a safe haven for ex "classy" topless bars|journal=[[New York (magazine)|New York]]|page=40|volume=27|issue=47|issn=0028-7369|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XeMCAAAAMBAJ&pg=PA41}}</ref> Steve Bachmann, on his book ''Simulating Sex: Aesthetic Representations of Erotic Activity'' pointed out that "perhaps one of the most interesting aspects of Madonna's sexual phenomenon is the extent to which her book marked a new threshold in the pornographic franchise".<ref name="Bachman 2">{{harvnb|Bachmann|2002|p=77}}</ref> Brian McNair, author of ''Striptease Culture: Sex, Media and the Democratisation of Desire'' (2012) praised this period of Madonna's career, saying that she had "porno elegance" and that "''Sex'' is the author of a cultural phenomenon of global proportions [due to the critics] and thanks to this Madonna established her iconic status and cultural influence.<ref name="McNair267">{{harvnb|McNair|2012|p=267}}</ref> Professors in ''Oh Fashion'' (1994) book felt that "Madonna is a toy for boys, but on another level boys are toys for her".<ref name="Oh" />
=== Queer and Gay === {{See also|Madonna as a gay icon}} [[File:Madonna Impersonator by David Shankbone.jpg|upright|thumb|LGBT [[Madonna wannabe|Madonna impersonator]].]]
According to ''[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]'', Madonna is the greatest gay icon of all time.<ref name="Advocate">{{cite web|url=http://www.advocate.com/print-issue/cover-stories/2012/02/02/madonna-truth-she-never-left-you|title=Madonna: The Truth Is She Never Left You|work=[[The Advocate (LGBT magazine)|The Advocate]]|date=February 2, 2012|accessdate=June 17, 2015|first=Ari|last=Karpel}}</ref> ''[[New Statesman]]'' reported that Madonna became the supreme gay icon, and the [[Madonna Studies]] analyzed and support these.<ref name="Statesman">{{cite journal|title=Madonna|year=2000|accessdate=June 23, 2015|volume=129|issue= 4493—4505|work=[[New Statesman]]|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=h_yFAAAAIAAJ&q=Madonna+a+gay+icon&dq=Madonna+a+gay+icon&hl=es-419&sa=X&ei=eZ2JVZvTEIaYNovuk-AI&ved=0CC4Q6AEwAzge|page=46|ref=harv}}</ref> Scholars Carmine Sarracino and Kevin Scott in ''The Porning of America'' (2008), wrote that Madonna "gained particular popularity with gay audiences, signaling the creation of a career-long fan base that would lead to her being hailed as the biggest gay icon of all time".<ref>{{harvnb|Sarracino|Scott|2002|p=93}}</ref> ''[[Out (magazine)|Out]]'' magazine wrote that Madonna "stuck her neck out and positioned herself to be a gay icon before it was cool to be one".<ref name="out">{{cite journal|title=Your Letters continued|year=2005|accessdate=June 23, 2015|volume=13|issue=7—12|work=[[Out (magazine)|Out]]|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=J_kiAQAAMAAJ&q=Madonna+is+a+gay+icon&dq=Madonna+is+a+gay+icon&hl=es-419&sa=X&ei=aqyJVbLjGcKyggT8sZnABA&ved=0CDAQ6AEwAzgK|page=178|ref=harv}}</ref>
[[Associate professor]] Judith A. Peraino wrote that "no one has worked harder to be a gay icon than Madonna, and she has done so by using every possible taboo sexual in her videos, performances, and interviews".<ref>{{harvnb|Peraino|2005|p=143}}</ref> Similar, Alex Hopkins from ''[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]]'' magazine denoted that gay community labeled her as [Their] 'Glorious Leader', "Madge is part of our subculture's rich history of diva worship. She has referenced every sacred monster from Dietrich to Monroe, revelled in upfront, often transgressive sexuality and demonstrated a highly developed sense of camp. No wonder we loved her". Also, her lack of inhibition helped inspire a generation of gay men and women to live on their own terms.<ref name="TimeOut">{{cite web|url=http://www.timeout.com/london/lgbt/is-madonna-still-the-ultimate-gay-icon|title=Is Madonna still the ultimate gay icon?|work=[[Time Out (magazine)|Time Out]]|date=August 11, 2011|accessdate=June 23, 2015|first=Alex|last=Hopkins}}</ref>
Madonna is also referred to as a queer icon and icon of queerness. [[Theologist]], [[Robert Goss]] wrote: "For me, Madonna has been not only a queer icon but also a Christ icon".<ref>{{harvnb|Goss|2002|p=178}}</ref> Similar Sheila Whiteley from ''Sexing the Groove: Popular Music and Gender'' (2013) felt that "Madonna came closer to any other contemporary celebrity in being an above-ground queer icon".<ref>{{harvnb|Whiteley|2013|p=275}}</ref>
=== Postmodern === According to [[Lucy O'Brien]]: Much has been made of Madonna as a postmodern icon, yet all her reference points have been resolutely modernist—from Steinbeck and Fitzgerald to Virginia Woolf and Sylvia Plath, to her predilection for narrative and psychoanalysis.<ref>{{harvnb|O'Brien|2007|p=27}}</ref>
Canadian editor [[Richard Appignanesi]] wrote that for some "Madonna is the cyber-model of the New Woman.<ref name="Appignanesi">{{Harvnb|Appignanesi|Garratt|2014|p=}}</ref> Similar, [[senior lecturer]]s Stéphanie Genz and Benjamin Brabon in ''Postfeminism: Cultural Texts and Theories'' (2009) felt that "whether it is as a woman, mother, pop icon or fifty year old, the American singer challenges our preconceptions of who 'Madonna' is and, more broadly, what these identity categories mean within a postmodern context".<ref>{{harvnb|Genz|Brabon|2009|p=118}}</ref>

== Contradictory perspective == [[File:Halloween-Parade feat. Madonna-Protest.jpg|left|thumb|A New Yorker protests Madonna adopting children from Africa on Halloween.]]
Professors in ''American Icons'' noted that she was not only an omnipresent figure but a [[Polarization (politics)|polarizing]] one. For example, in 1993, she was the subject of the ''I Hate Madonna Handbook'' and the following year the inspirations for ''I Dream of Madonna''.<ref name="Hall">{{harvnb|Hall|2006|pp=446}}</ref> [[Lynn Spigel]] noted that Madonna is a producer of cultural ambiguity and openness.<ref name="Spiegel23">{{harvnb|Spigel|2007|pp=123}}</ref> [[Rabbi]] Isaac Karudi —the highest authority of the Orthodox [[Kabbalah]]— described her as a "depraved [[cultural icon]]".<ref name="ElMundo">{{cite web|url=http://www.elmundo.es/cronica/2004/461/1092757010.html|title=Los pecados que ya no cometerás|last=Vidal|first=Jose Manuel|work=El Mundo|location=Spain|accessdate=April 15, 2015|language=Spanish}}</ref> Social critic and [[Critical theory|critical theorist]], [[Stuart Sim]] noted that "Madonna now attained the status of cultural icon, she is however, an extremely problematic one, as her delight in simultaneously evoking and transgressing cultural stereotypes of feminity makes her exceedingly difficult to categorize; {{Quote|quote="Madonna’s celebrity is unique in that it seems to depend as much on repugnance as on acceptance. During her career, Madonna attracted the attention of family organizations, feminist "[[Opposition to pornography|anti-porn]]" and religious groups worldwide with boycott and protests. Professor Bruce David Forbes author of ''Religion and Popular Culture in America'' (2005) felt that "some of the most important and interesting texts in recent American culture which have overlapping concerns with liberation theologies are by Madonna".<ref name="Forbes">{{harvnb|Forbes|2005|pp=75}}</ref> Karen Fredericks from socialist newspaper ''[[Green Left Weekly]]'' questioned if does the "Madonna phenomenon" advance the cause of women's liberation within [[Western societies]]? she said that clearly, there's no point going to Madonna for help. She asserted that the artist is a commodity in a [[capitalist]] market which has been influenced, at least to some extent, by the demands of the women's movement.<ref name="GreenLeftWeekly"/> Sociologist John Shepherd wrote that Madonna's cultural practices highlight the sadly continuing social realities of dominance and subordination.<ref name="john" /> In 1988, one Italian sculptor planned a statue of Madonna in [[Pacentro]], where are from her paternal grandparents, who said "Madonna is a symbol of our children and represents a better world in the year 2000". The then mayor of the city declared: "it is absolutely untrue that the city administration of Pacentro is willing to host the statue to the singer Madonna as some maintain".<ref name="Statue">{{Cite news|url=http://articles.philly.com/1988-01-06/news/26284162_1_e-streeters-dates-and-venues-honorary-citizen|title=Statue Of Madonna Is Debated|date=January 6, 1988|accessdate=June 17, 2015|publisher=[[Philadelphia Media Network]]|author=W. Speers}}</ref><ref name="StatueAP">{{Cite news|url=http://articles.philly.com/1988-01-06/news/26284162_1_e-streeters-dates-and-venues-honorary-citizen|title=Statue of Madonna won't stand in Italy|date=January 8, 1988|accessdate=June 17, 2015|work=[[The Gettysburg Times]]|author=[[Associated Press]] (AP)}}</ref>
Academic Audra Gaugler from [[Lehigh University]] advocated for Madonna, wrote that "she has faced much criticism throughout her career, but much of it is unjust. Instead of Madonna's actions eliciting criticism, they should elicit praise because she radically tries to change society by blurring the boundaries that separate different groups of people in society and she urges all people to gain power in their lives and lift themselves out of subordinate positions. Madonna blurs the boundaries that exist in society and separate people in society in two distinct ways". She noted that there exists a large band of critics that at first praised her, but then became disillusioned with her as she became more and more controversial.<ref name="Gaugler">{{Cite news|url=http://preserve.lehigh.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1662&context=etd|title=Madonna, an American pop icon of feminism and counter-hegemony : blurring the boundaries [sic] of race, gender, and sexuality by Audra Gaugler.|year=2000|accessdate=June 18, 2015|publisher=[[Lehigh University]]|first=Audra|last=Gaugler}}</ref>

A '''curb stomp''', also called curbing, curb checking, curb painting, or making someone '''bite the curb''' is a form of [[assault]] in which a victim's mouth is forcefully placed on a [[curb]] and then [[Stomp (strike)|stomped]] from behind, causing severe [[injury|injuries]] and sometimes [[death]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/more-arrests-in-curb-stomping-death-1.246543|title=More arrests in curb stomping death|publisher=CBC News|date=2000-06-03|accessdate=2014-05-04}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| work=Gangland |title=VolksFront|date=November 28, 2014}}</ref>
== Notable incidents == * In July 2002, 16-year old German Marinus Schöberl was tortured by young, underage neo-Nazis in an abandoned pigsty in [[Oberuckersee]] (in the German state of [[Brandenburg]]) and killed after curb-stomping. The main perpetrator, who was 17 at the time of the killing, was released after serving eight years in prison.<ref> https://www.presseportal.de/pm/2790/1736137</ref> * In 2003, [[Tacoma, Washington]] resident Randall Townsend was murdered by four people. David Nikos Pillatos, Scotty James Butters, and Tristain Lynn Frye beat and kicked Townsend while Kurtis William Monschke delivered the final blow: curb-stomping. Monschke had recently been named head of the Washington chapter of [[Volksfront]]. "Prosecutors said the attack was meant to lift Monschke's status in the [[white supremacist]] movement and to earn Frye a pair of red shoelaces, with the red signifying the drawing of blood." <ref>{{cite web|url=https://caselaw.findlaw.com/wa-court-of-appeals/1197904.html|title=''STATE v. MONSCHKE'', No. 31847-4-II (WN. 2006).|publisher=}}</ref> <ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.splcenter.org/fighting-hate/intelligence-report/2004/kurtis-monschke-and-other-racists-commit-violent-killing}}</ref>
Tristain Lynn Frye was sentenced to 13 years, nine months for [[second-degree murder]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://lmtribune.com/northwest/woman-sentenced-in-transient-s-killing/article_d1a9e5cb-caa2-59d0-a0ed-480a7452cd4e.html}}</ref>
Scotty James Butters and David Nikos Pillatos pled to [[first-degree murder]], accepted a plea agreement and testified against Monschke in exchange for being able to request that their imprisonment be no more than approximately 30 years. in June 2004, the [[U.S. Supreme Court]] ruled "a sentence longer than the standard range could not be ordered by a judge without action by a jury, meaning Butters and Pillatos could face no more than 31 years in prison." <ref>{{cite web|url=https://culteducation.com/group/1173-white-supremacists/19842-court-bars-move-for-extra-long-sentences-in-transient-stomping-death.html}}</ref>
Kurtis William Monschke was convicted of aggravated first degree murder and sentenced to life in prison without possibility of parole. The incident has been described as a [[hate crime]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.thenewstribune.com/soundlife/v-printerfriendly/story/201056.html|title=Tacoma murder revisited}}</ref>
* On August 26, 2011, Dane Hall was curb stomped in an attack outside a [[gay bar]] in Salt Lake City, Utah. He lost six teeth and suffered a broken jaw as a result of the attack.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.deseretnews.com/article/705390124/Gay-man-severely-beaten-outside-club-says-he-was-victim-of-hate-crime.html?pg=all|title=Gay man severely beaten outside club says he was victim of hate crime|publisher=Deseret News|author=Pat Reavy|date=September 1, 2011}}</ref>
[[Junko Furuta]], a Japanese high school girl, was curb stomped among the various other tortures inflicted on her before her death.
== Cultural references == On the twentieth season of American television series ''[[Big Brother 20 (U.S.)|Big Brother]]'', Houseguest Sam Bledsoe defines for fellow Houseguest J.C. Mounduix a "curb stomp" and terrifies him in the process.
In the film ''[[American History X]]'' (1998), [[white power skinhead]] Derek Vinyard curb-stomps Lawrence, an African American burglar who had tried to steal his truck.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.complex.com/pop-culture/2013/05/most-hard-to-watch-scenes-in-movie-history/american-history-x|title=50 Most Hard-To-Watch scenes in movie history|publisher=Complex Pop Culture|author1=Matt Barone|author2=Javy Rodriguez|author3=Ross Scarano|author4=Tara Aquino|date=May 5, 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://trueslant.com/johnsellers/2009/07/27/curb-stomp-an-oral-history-of-the-grisly-american-history-x-scene/|title=Curb-Stomp — An Oral History of the Grisly ‘American History X’ Scene|publisher=True Slant|author=John Sellers|date=July 27, 2009|accessdate=May 4, 2014}}</ref>
New Jersey mafia boss [[Tony Soprano]] curb stomps New York mobster [[List of characters from The Sopranos in the Lupertazzi crime family#Salvatore "Coco" Cogliano|Salvatore "Coco" Cogliano]] for making lewd comments to [[Meadow Soprano|his daughter]] in ''[[The Sopranos]]'' episode "[[The Second Coming (The Sopranos)|The Second Coming]]" (2007).
[[WWE]] professional wrestler [[Seth Rollins]] previously used a [[Professional wrestling attacks#Curb stomp|Curb Stomp]] as his finishing move. Rollins said that he stopped using the move as "from a PR standpoint... it was too perceptually violent... I never hurt anyone with it. It was just something we didn't want kids trying on each other".<ref>{{cite web|last1=Traina|first1=Jimmy|title=Seth Rollins talks Brock Lesnar, Johnny Manziel, curb stomp, John Cena and more|url=http://www.foxsports.com/buzzer/story/wwe-seth-rollins-brock-lesnar-jonhhy-manziel-john-cena-battleground-071615|publisher=[[Fox Sports]]|accessdate=December 14, 2015}}</ref> On the January 15, 2018, edition of ''[[Monday Night Raw]]'', Rollins used the move once again to win a match against [[Finn Bálor]], with announcer [[Corey Graves]] referring to it as the "Blackout".
In the Bollywood movie ''[[Shootout at Lokhandwala]]'', a scene is depicted where [[Vivek Oberoi]] curb stomps a local resident who informs the police about Aslam (Oberoi's friend) who is encountered by the police.
A track by American hip hop artist [[JPEGMAFIA]] named after the act was included on his second album ''Veteran''.

Roberts]] | illustrator = | cover_artist = | country = | language = | series = | subject = Death and dying | genre = | publisher = [http://www.newsagepress.com/ New Sage] | release_date = January, 2002 | english_release_date = | media_type = trade paper | pages = 100 | isbn = 0-939165-43-0 | dewey= 155.9/37 21 | congress= BF789.D4 R58 2002 | oclc= 48515581 | preceded_by = | followed_by = }} '''''Death Without Denial Grief Without Apology: A Guide for Facing Death and Loss''''' by former [[Governor of Oregon|Oregon Governor]] [[Barbara Roberts|Barbara K. Roberts]] is a personal narrative of the author's experiences during her husband, [[Frank L. Roberts|Frank]]'s battle with [[cancer]], the final year of his life, and the subsequent years of grieving.
At the time of Frank Roberts' fatal recurrence of the illness, both he and his wife were in public office, Barbara as governor, and Frank as [[state senator]]. They turned to hospice for guidance and assistance once Frank decided to stop medical intervention.
Touching on matters of life with terminal illness, death with dignity, and both the personal and societal issues surrounding death, chapter titles include “A Culture in Denial,” “Hospice,” and “Permission to be Weird.”

{{notability|date=May 2017}} {{italic title}} {{Infobox film | name = Death by Design | image = | alt = | caption = | film name = | director = Peter Friedman
Jean-François Brunet | producer = | writer = | screenplay = | story = | based on = | starring = | narrator = | music = | cinematography = | editing = | studio = | distributor = | released = {{film date|1995}} | runtime = | country = | language = | budget = | gross = }} '''''Death by Design''''' is a 1995 [[science]] [[documentary]] directed by Peter Friedman and Jean-François Brunet of the [[Ecole Normale Supérieure in Paris]] which focuses on [[cell biology]], with an emphasis on [[programmed cell death]] and why our lives depend on it.{{cite web|title=Netflix - Watch TV Shows Online, Watch Movies Online |url=http://www.netflix.com/Movie/Death-by-Design-The-Life-and-Times-of-Life-and-Times/70033351 |website=www.netflix.com |accessdate=15 April 2017}} Featured are prominent [[biologist]]s such as [[Nobel prize laureate]] [[Rita Levi-Montalcini]] (along with her artist [[twin]] sister [[Paola Levi-Montalcini]]), [[Martin Raff]], [[Polly Matzinger]], [[Pierre Goldstein]], and Nobel laureate[[Robert Horvitz]]. The documentary is notable for its combination of a whimsical use of metaphors with scientific rigor, and incorporates [[animation]], [[micro-cinematography]], and scenes from old [[Hollywood]] films and [[stock footage]], including [[Busby Berkley]]-choreographed [[dance]] routines. The opening scene features the trailer from the 1950s [[science fiction film]] ''[[It Came From Outer Space]]''. == External links == *{{IMDb title|118947}} ==References== {{Reflist}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Death by Design}} [[Category:Animated documentary films]] [[Category:Programmed cell death]] [[Category:Documentary films about science]] [[Category:Documentary films about death]] {{sci-documentary-film-stub}}

'''Estampage''' or stamping, is a term commonly used in [[epigraphy]] to obtain the exact replica of an inscription that cannot be transported.
According to Jayanti Madhukar,<ref name="jayanti_hindu_blr_2017">{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/society/what-do-the-inscription-stones-of-bengaluru-say/article21670654.ece|title=What do the inscription stones of Bengaluru say?|last=Madhukar|first=Jayanthi|date=2017-12-16|work=The Hindu|access-date=2017-12-19|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}}</ref> it is defined as: {{Quote |text=''a process of ‘lifting’ the inscriptions from the stone on to a piece of paper for a clearer read'' }} The [[Merriam-Webster Dictionary]] defines it as:<ref name="dict_mw">{{Cite web|url=https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/estampage|title=Definition of ESTAMPAGE|website=www.merriam-webster.com|language=en|access-date=2017-12-19}}</ref> {{Quote |text=''an impression of an inscription made on inked paper'' }}
== Etymology == According to T.S. Ravishankar, former director of the Epigraphy branch of the [[Archaeological Survey of India]] (ASI), Estampage is a purely Indian term used by [[Epigraphist]]s.<ref name="jayanti_hindu_blr_2017"/> However, a more linguistically correct explanation would be that it originated from the French word [[:wikt:fr:estampage|estampage]] (by itself of Proto-Germanic etymology) that literally means 'stamping' and in practice, can mean either of the two processes, namely industrial stamping of steel ([[forging]]) or the artistic stamping of various materials. The latter meaning seems to be have been adopted into epigraphy.
== Process of estampage == Estampage is typically obtained by pressing wet paper on to the rock face, over which any ink material (usually, coal or [[India ink|Indian ink]]) is wiped.<ref name="Springer_ACCV14_process">{{Cite book|last=Aswatha|first=Shashaank M.|last2=Talla|first2=Ananth Nath|last3=Mukhopadhyay|first3=Jayanta|last4=Bhowmick|first4=Partha|date=2014-11-01|title=A Method for Extracting Text from Stone Inscriptions Using Character Spotting|journal=Computer Vision - ACCV 2014 Workshops|series=Lecture Notes in Computer Science|language=en|publisher=Springer, Cham|pages=598–611|doi=10.1007/978-3-319-16631-5_44|isbn=9783319166308}}</ref>
An representative procedure<ref name="Springer_ACCV14_process"/> is listed below: * Soak a brush in water * Clean the surface of the stone (that holds the inscription) using the brush. * Carpet the stone surface using a large piece of wet paper (or layers of paper) * Pat the wet paper(s) gently, using a [[dabber]] made of soft material. * Use Indian ink (usually black-colored) to smear the paper with the dabber, in order to get the impression of the surface. * Allow the paper to dry on the stone surface. * When the paper becomes dry, take it off slowly. * Observe and verify the ink impression (estampage) emerging as white-colored letters (grooves of the characters) against the dark (black) background.
Epigraphers usually take a long time (days to weeks) to post-process the generated estampages, as they try to decipher, analyze, transliterate and translate the inscribed text.
== Usage == Within India, estampages have been made for numerous items and inscriptions of archaeological significance.<ref name="book_indian_epigraphy">{{Cite book|title=Indian Epigraphy : a Guide to the Study of Inscriptions in Sanskrit, Prakrit, and the other Indo-Aryan Languages.|last=1948-|first=Salomon, Richard|date=1998|publisher=Oxford University Press|isbn=978-0195356663|location=New York|oclc=466425560}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.tnarch.gov.in/epi.htm|title=EPIGRAPHY - ARCHAEOLOGY|website=www.tnarch.gov.in|access-date=2017-12-19}}</ref> Some of them include: * [[Edicts of Ashoka]] and [[Edicts of Ashoka#Estampages of Girnar Edicts|Estampages of Girnar Edicts]] in particular * [[Madho Sarup Vats]] * Works by [[Tamil Nadu Archaeology Department]] * Works by [[M. G. S. Narayanan]] * [[Syriac language|Syriac]]/[[Middle Persian|Pahlavi]] inscriptions of [[Kerala]] <ref name="jstor_pahlavi_kerala">{{Cite journal|last=Winckworth|first=C. P. T.|date=1929|title=A NEW INTERPRETATION OF THE PAHLAVI CROSS-INSCRIPTIONS OF SOUTHERN INDIA|jstor=23950669|journal=The Journal of Theological Studies|volume=30|issue=119|pages=237–244}}</ref>
== Museums and displays == In 2016, the epigraphy branch of the ASI Southern Zone opened a new, permanent museum and exhibition of estampages named ''Eugen Julius Theodor Hultzsch Memorial Museum and Epigraphical Photo Exhibition'' at the historic [[Fort St. George, India|Fort St. George]] at [[Chennai]], South India. This museum is named after [[E. Hultzsch]], a German epigraphist and [[Indology|Indologist]], renowned for understanding and deciphering the ancient inscriptions of Ashoka as part of his 159th birthday celebrations.<ref name="thehindu_museum_chennai">{{Cite news|url=http://www.thehindu.com/news/cities/chennai/asi-opens-museum-of-estampages-from-across-india/article8407198.ece|title=ASI opens museum of estampages from across India|last=Swaminathan|first=T. s Atul|date=2016-03-29|work=The Hindu|access-date=2017-12-19|language=en-IN|issn=0971-751X}}</ref>
== See also == * [[Fernand Courby]], a French archaeologist * [http://www.mom.fr/estampages/presentation.html Collection of over 10,000 estampages from Greece and Middle East] at [[Maison de l'Orient et de la Méditerranée]], Lyon, France
